profileText: A Representative from Michigan; born in Cobleskill, Schoharie County, N.Y., February 21, 1838; attended the common schools and Genesee Wesleyan Seminary at Lima, N.Y.; moved to Oxford, Oakland County, Mich., in 1856; taught school; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice at Flint, Genesee County, Mich., in 1858; member of the board of education; member of the board of aldermen 1862-1867; mayor of Flint in 1873 and 1874; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-fourth Congress (March 4, 1875-March 3, 1877); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1876 to the Forty-fifth Congress; resumed the practice of his profession; appointed temporarily justice of the Michigan Supreme Court in 1892; president of the State board of law examiners for many years; appointed special assistant United States attorney in Chinese and opium smuggling cases in Oregon and served from 1893 to 1896; died in Flint, Mich., June 8, 1903; interment in Glenwood Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1862-1912; 4 volumes, 3 folders, and 2 oversize items.
researchRecord.description: The scrapbooks of George H. Durand contain business and legal papers, a manuscript address, and scattered correspondence from 1876 dealing with Democratic politics. Also included are scrapbooks of newspaper clippings on legal business, politics, and his death, as well as papers concerning the presentation of George H. Durand's portrait to the Michigan Supreme Court.

recordLocation.name: Michigan Historical Collections, Bentley Historical Library
